bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, February 20, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Spies that Hench's paper from the recent Havana conference has been revised and edited. He thanks Spies for the hospitality shown him in Havana, expresses his pride in receiving the Finlay medal, and asks Spies' help in acquiring a translation of Andreu's remarks made at the medal ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, February 20, 1952
div1.opener:
February 20, 1952
Dr. Tom D. Spies
Nutrition Clinic
Hillman Hospital
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Tom:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for your kind letter of February 7. The crossing the
night we left was indeed pretty rough. Mary and I took Dramamine at
the pier and when we saw just outside the harbor how rough it was, we
took another one, went to our cabin and went to bed. Dramamine always
makes us both quite sleepy so we promptly went to sleep, woke up about
11, ordered some supper in our cabin and spent a very comfortable night,
thanks to Dramamine.

On the train coming home however I caught a bad cold and felt rather
miserable the first few days after we got home. Despite this you will
be happy to know that I have finished the paper, made all necessary re-
visions, added a fairly comprehensive bibliography and now it is in the
hands of our Editorial Department who have already edited it. In a
very few days it will be sent directly to Europe as you request and a
copy will be sent to you.

Tom, let me express again to you my very deep appreciation for the very
kind and generous hospitality which you, your Cuban friends and your own
delightful secretarial party extended to Mary and me. You gave us one
of the memorable trips of our lives. I never saw a man try more to
make his guests comfortable and welcome. As I said to you, next to
the Stockholm hospitality your hospitality to us in Havana takes the
prize.

Let me say again how much I appreciated what you and Mrs. Smith did in
regard to the Finlay Medal. This is my only decoration and of course
gives me a particular pleasure. I consider it a real honor, especially
as you also wear the Finlay Medal.

Please tell Betty, Jean, and Eleanor that I have sent the pictures off
to be developed. As soon as they come I will send copies along. I leave
tomorrow for five days in Washington but will be back the first of the week.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Out of curiosity and sentimality, I should like to have a copy of the
English translation of Dr. Andreu's remarks made at the time of the decora-
tion ceremony. I was told that Mario LeRoy was the man who translated Dr.
Andreu's speech but I could not find his name in the telephone book. I am
writing to Dr. Nogueira asking if he will get a copy of Dr. Andreu's speech
for me through Mr. or Dr. LeRoy. If you happen to see him the next time you
are in Havana, I would appreciate it if you would ask him whether he has been
asked to send one along.
